org.jcvi.jillion.trace.fastq

Class FastqUtil

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jcvi.jillion.trace.fastq.FastqUtil

  • public final class FastqUtil
extends Object
    FastqUtil is a utility class for working with FASTQ data.
    Author:
    dkatzel

    • Field Detail

      • SEQ_DEFLINE_PATTERN

        public static final Pattern SEQ_DEFLINE_PATTERN
        This is the Pattern to parse the sequence record defline of a FASTQ record. Group 1 will be the read id Group 3 will be the optional comment if there is one, or null if there isn't a comment.

    • Method Detail

      • guessQualityCodecUsed

        public static FastqQualityCodec guessQualityCodecUsed(File fastqFile)
                                               throws IOException
        Attempts to guess the FastqQualityCodec used to encode the qualities in the given fastq file. This method works by analyzing the encoded quality value ranges for each read getting inspected. Since all the different quality encodings have overlapping values the FastqQualityCodec used for the entire file can not always be determined from just analyzing a few reads. Therefore, this method might have to parse ALL records in the fastq file to guarantee that the correct FastqQualityCodec is returned.
        Parameters:
        fastqFile - a fastq File, must exist and can not be null.
        Returns:
        an instance of FastqQualityCodec which is the one that is most likely able to decode the quality values for all the reads in the file (will never be null).
        Throws:
        IOException - if there is a problem reading the file.
        NullPointerException - if fastqFile is null.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given quality string is empty or if it contains any characters out of range of any known quality encoding formats.
        IllegalStateException - if the fastq file does not contain any records.

      • guessQualityCodecUsed

        public static FastqQualityCodec guessQualityCodecUsed(File fastqFile,
                                                      int numberOfReadsToInspect)
                                               throws IOException
        Attempts to guess the FastqQualityCodec used to encode the qualities in the given fastq file. This method works by analyzing the encoded quality value ranges for each read getting inspected. Since all the different quality encodings have overlapping values the FastqQualityCodec used for the entire file can not always be determined from just analyzing a few reads. Therefore, this method must parse many (probably hundreds) of reads in the fastq file in order to get a large enough sampling size to confidently return a FastqQualityCodec. This method will keep looking at reads in the fastq file until either the file ends, or it has looked at numberOfReadsToInspect.
        Parameters:
        fastqFile - a fastq File, must exist and can not be null.
        numberOfReadsToInspect - the number of reads in the file to analyze.
        Returns:
        an instance of FastqQualityCodec which is the one that is most likely able to decode the quality values for all the reads in the file (will never be null).
        Throws:
        IOException - if there is a problem reading the file.
        NullPointerException - if fastqFile is null.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given quality string is empty or if it contains any characters out of range of any known quality encoding formats.
        IllegalArgumentException - if numberOfReadsToInspect is < 1.
        IllegalStateException - if the fastq file does not contain any records.

      • guessQualityCodecUsed

        public static FastqQualityCodec guessQualityCodecUsed(FastqParser parser)
                                               throws IOException
        Attempts to guess the FastqQualityCodec used to encode the qualities in the given fastq file. This method works by analyzing the encoded quality value ranges for each read getting inspected. Since all the different quality encodings have overlapping values the FastqQualityCodec used for the entire file can not always be determined from just analyzing a few reads. Therefore, this method might have to parse ALL records in the fastq file to guarantee that the correct FastqQualityCodec is returned.
        Parameters:
        parser - a FastqParser instance to parse; must exist and can not be null.
        Returns:
        an instance of FastqQualityCodec which is the one that is most likely able to decode the quality values for all the reads in the file (will never be null).
        Throws:
        IOException - if there is a problem reading the file.
        NullPointerException - if fastqFile is null.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given quality string is empty or if it contains any characters out of range of any known quality encoding formats.
        IllegalStateException - if the fastq file does not contain any records.

      • guessQualityCodecUsed

        public static FastqQualityCodec guessQualityCodecUsed(FastqParser parser,
                                                      int numberOfReadsToInspect)
                                               throws IOException
        Attempts to guess the FastqQualityCodec used to encode the qualities in the given fastq file. This method works by analyzing the encoded quality value ranges for each read getting inspected. Since all the different quality encodings have overlapping values the FastqQualityCodec used for the entire file can not always be determined from just analyzing a few reads. Therefore, this method must parse many (probably hundreds) of reads in the fastq file in order to get a large enough sampling size to confidently return a FastqQualityCodec. This method will keep looking at reads in the fastq file until either the file ends, or it has looked at numberOfReadsToInspect.
        Parameters:
        parser - a FastqParser instance to parse; must exist and can not be null.
        numberOfReadsToInspect - the number of reads in the file to analyze.
        Returns:
        an instance of FastqQualityCodec which is the one that is most likely able to decode the quality values for all the reads in the file (will never be null).
        Throws:
        IOException - if there is a problem reading the file.
        NullPointerException - if fastqFile is null.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given quality string is empty or if it contains any characters out of range of any known quality encoding formats.
        IllegalArgumentException - if numberOfReadsToInspect is < 1.
        IllegalStateException - if the fastq file does not contain any records.
